repository.corpname: Western Connecticut State University Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: This collection contains many clippings, administrative materials, and materials related to the different international pavillions. The collection also contains 60 tapes and supporting materials of interviews conducted through by Greater Danbury Intercultural Association to document the contituent groups that make up the greater Danbury area.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Likely tranfered to the Archives through Dr. Ellen Rosenbeg. 2016 accretion, gift of Mary Burke.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with some restrictions.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Greater Danbury Intercultural Association Interviews; MS 064; box number; folder number; Western Connecticut State University

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Greater Danbury Intercultural Association was created by the City of Danbury in an effort to preserve the heritage of the local people. Dr. Harold Burke was chairman and Andrew DeGrazia was the president. One of Greater Danbury Intercultural Association's projects was to seek out persons from the wide variety of ethnicities that make up the western Connecticut area and interviewing them on topics they felt it was important to preserve regarding their ethnic cultures. That project is present in the forty-six tapes and the five transcripts in our collection. Another project of the Greater Danbury Intercultural Association was the Danbury Ethnic Cultural Festival which ran from 1980 - 1995.

The Danbury Ethnic Cultural Festival was a volunteer project, and related activities/events were free and open to the public. The festivals were annual 3-day events and relied upon volunteer support and the sale of raffle tickets to remain in operation. WCSU was acknowledged as a supporter of the Danbury Ethnic Cultural Festival.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This is a small collection of forty-six tapes, three reel-to-reels, five interview transcripts and newspaper clipping from the Greater Danbury Intercultural Association. The tapes consist of interviews with local immigrants about their heritage. Topics of the interviews include folk tales, language, history, and music. There are five transcribed interviews that correlate with interviews on tape in this collection. [Tape 3 and 11 were blank and removed from the inventory].

In 2016 an accretion to the collection expanded the materials in the collection to include administative materials, clippings, and materials related to the country pavillions that were present at different festivals.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Tapes are arranged in the same order that they were arranged when delivered to the Archives.
The materials are grouped into 4 series:

archref.extref: Danbury Remembers â€“ Conversations With a Community : Danbury History Project Oral Histories

controlaccess.subject: Immigration to the United States.
Ethnic groups -- United States -- History -- 20th century.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Series includes: Constitutions, original papers of orginization, administrative boards and commitees, legal-permits and orders, financial grants, correspondence, rules and regulation documents, directories of member groups, and procedural directives.

The financial materials included in this collection were donated to provide evidence that appropriate procedures were followed and to provide examples of the process of maintaining the Intercultural Association and conducting their different activities. All of the printing for the Intercultural Association was performed by a Mr. Connie Shuler, who lived in Danbury during the time, and the Association's bank account was kept with Union Savings Bank - Danbury. After the disolution of the Greater Danbury Intercultural Association the funds remaining in the account were donated to the Danbury Museum and Historical Society.

did.unittitle: Display of Art and Handiwork G.I.D.A

odd.head: General
odd.p: When the Danbury Intercultural Association began it sent announcements to known ethnic groups in the greater Danbury area. Over time the nature of the relationship between different local ethcnic groups and the Association changed as the members and organization of different local ethnic related groups changed. Collaboration with the Greater Danbury Intercultural Association was also an opportunity for lesser known ethnic groups to gain recognition within the community, while it also provided a platform for all associated groups to host their own events.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The Greater Danbury Intercultural Association oral history project lead them to seek out persons from the wide variety of ethnicities that make up the western Connecticut area and interview them about their heritage, their lives, and on topics they felt were important to preserve regarding their cultures.
That project resulted in the forty-six tapes and five transcripts in this collection.

daodesc.p: Keewaydinoquay, an Ojibwa from Michigan talks about Indian Healing : undated

odd.head: General
odd.p: Keewaydinoquay, an Ojibwa from Michigan, will meet visitors and talk about Indian healing tommorrow at 1:30 PM in the American Indian Archaeological Institute, Route 199, Washington, Conn.

Keewaydinoquay, "Woman-of-the-Northwest-Wind", is a member of the Crane Clan of the Anishinaabeg Nation. Apprenticed at the age of nine to an Ojibwa mahkwe, she was intitiated into Midewiwin, the Ojibwa medicine society. She has practiced healing for more than 50 years. Admission is by donation.

odd.head: General
odd.p: This series contains transcripts of five of the oral history interviews conducted with local persons by the Greater Danbury Intercultural Association and some miscellaneous materials related to the annual Intercultural Festival.
